Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ocean Remote Sensing Using Ambient Noise
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: In recent years it has been shown theoretically that, under very weak assumptions, a good approximation to the acoustic Green's function G(A, B, t) can be extracted by computing the cross-correlation of simultaneous measurements of ambient acoustic noise at locations A and B. G(A, B, t) is the response at location A to an impulsive point source at location B; by reciprocity G(A, B, t) = G(B, A, t) in a quiescent environment. This procedure is sometimes referred to as noise interferometry. The practical utility of noise interferometry has been demonstrated in a variety of settings, including seismic applications. Because this technique does not involve the use of active acoustic sources, it requires only very modest experimental resources. This project seeks to demonstrate the feasibility of noise interferometry in the ocean, and explore several issues relevant to understanding the limitations of noise interferometry for ocean remote sensing. The work involves a combination of experiment, data analysis, theory and numerical simulations. It is anticipated to provide a foundation for using noise interferometry as a practical means of acoustic remote sensing of the ocean's interior, and to that end the focus will be on using real ocean data to demonstrate the utility of the method under practical ocean conditions, rather than such things as idealized simulations.

Broader Impacts: The proposed work has applications to several fields with obvious societal benefits. These include noninvasive medical ultrasound for diagnostic and monitoring purposes, and nondestructive evaluation of structures, e.g., crack detection in bridges using only traffic-generated vibrations. In addition to developing the tools to understand and address these problems, the project will support and train two graduate students. For ocean remote sensing, the ability to use ambient sound for remote sensing of the ocean volume eliminates the possibility of harming marine life with active sound sources. The work will be done in loose, unfunded collaboration with a small group of Russian scientists, thereby contributing to the strengthening of international ties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was devoted to investigation of a possible use of ambient and shipping noise in the ocean to probe the environment, much like a person uses daylight to learn about their surroundings. With little or no knowledge about noise sources and their location, quantitative information about physical parameters of the water column and seafloor can be retrieved from the cross-correlation function of noise concurrently measured by two spatially separated hydrophones. Such an approach is referred to as noise interferometry. It is a passive remote sensing technique and does not require any dedicated sound sources. Passive acoustic techniques do not contribute to noise pollution in the ocean and are inherently environmentally friendly.

The project centered on the data we obtained in a series of deployments of three simple, single-hydrophone autonomous systems in the Straits of Florida. In each deployment, underwater acoustic noise was simultaneously recorded at three locations for a period from one week to a few months.  A year-long time series of ambient noise, which was measured off Ascension Island in the Central Atlantic by hydrophones that are maintained by the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization, served as an additional source of data for noise interferometry.

We have demonstrated experimentally that noise-interferometry-based passive acoustic remote sensing of the ocean is feasible at ranges as large as 100 ocean depths. This is the main outcome of the project. We have shown that acoustic noise interferometry can provide accurate absolute measurements of depth-averaged current velocity in the ocean with sufficiently high temporal resolution. Our experimental results suggest feasibility of a low-cost, environmentally friendly passive acoustic system for monitoring the heat and mass transfer in the ocean.

In the course of the project, several gradient students have acquired the necessary broad educational background to pursue careers in physical oceanography and geosciences, including the valuable experience of working on a research vessel at sea.

Our findings have significant implications for other research fields. The results of our investigation of long-range correlations of acoustic pressure fluctuations in the ocean, which were obtained using hydrophones on long moorings, indicate that hydrophone-equipped autonomous underwater vehicles and floats can provide useful data for interferometric studies of the seafloor in the microseism frequency band. In this frequency band, two-point cross-correlations of pressure fluctuations in the water column prove to be sensitive to upper-crustal shear velocities. In marine seismology, hydrophone-equipped floats can supplement or even provide an alternative to higher-cost measurements with ocean bottom seismometers. In application to atmospheric sciences, the acoustic noise interferometry technique, which we developed for measuring velocity of oceanic currents, have been shown to provide low-cost measurements of path-averaged air temperature and wind speed and direction. The technique can serve as a basis for passive acoustic tomography of the atmospheric boundary layer.
